title: FF Legato
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Typefaces](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Typefaces) : FF Legato**

The following text about FF Legato was written by its creator, [Evert Bloemsma](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Evert%20Bloemsma) in [this <cite>About FF Legato</cite> PDF file](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/files/ff%20-%20legato_about.pdf).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733im_/http:/typophile.com/files/legato110906pdh01_5788.gif)
  
Most [sanserifs](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/sans%20serif) have very basic geometric shapes (like [Futura](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Futura)), even those built using classical proportions (like [Gill Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Gill%20Sans)). But this is not the most satisfactory approach when trying to visually connect separate characters, which in turn usually leads to most long texts being set in serifed typefaces.

FF Legato abandons the idea of a sanserif consisting of simple rigid forms. The mirrored image below shows how (different from typefaces like Gill Sans and [Syntax](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Syntax)) movement and direction is expressed by outer- and inner-forms behaving relatively independent, and is maintained through all [weights](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/weight). It makes characters refer to previous and next letters to build better words and lines.

Many sanserifs published these days combine a ‘pleasant’ appearance with a conventional construction. This is just what I wanted to avoid designing FF Legato. In discussions FF Legato has been compared with typefaces like [Finnegan](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Finnegan) ( [Linotype](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Linotype)) and [Cronos](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Cronos) ( [Adobe](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Adobe)). [Contrast](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Contrast) of such faces is strong and along a single vertical [axis](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/axis); vertical bars are emphasized. This becomes clear when looking at a character like the lowercase ‘o’ at bolder weights. The construction establishes a strong rhythm but does not necessarily improve word images.

On the contrary; it optically splits up words into single letters with stems as independant elements, just as our alphabet already splits up terms in separate units on a ‘system-level’. Often the resulting austerity is then masked, for example by decorative details suggesting the touch of a brush or nib. Such typefaces will work fine for packaging etc. but their use for larger texts is questionable and they may not fit contemporary, transparent graphic design.

In [1993](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/1993) my rather experimental [FF Balance](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/FF%20Balance) was published. It completely reverses the conventional contrast (‘incorrect contrast’); horizontal parts are thicker than vertical parts. The illustration below compares the sanserifs [Univers](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Univers) (emphasizing vertical parts), FF Balance (emphasizing horizontal parts) and FF Legato (emphasizing diagonals from the upper left to the lower right). Each one of them builds a different rhythm, creates a different interaction between the characters; a different continuity.

FF Legato was recognized as one of its [Favorite Fonts of 2004](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typographi.com/000969.php) by the type blog, [Typographica](http://web.archive.org/web/20130729075733/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Typographica).
